introduction.p:
In a Carnot engine a fixed amount of ideal gas is heated and cooled in a particular cyclic process called the Carnot cycle. The Carnot cycle consists of four steps shown in .
Isothermal expansion at high temperature T_H.
Adiabatic expansion lowering temperature from T_H to T_C.
Isothermal compression at lower temperature T_C.
Adiabatic compression raising temperature from T_C to T_H.
The states A, B, C, and D are chosen so that at the end of these four steps, the system returns to state A.

figure.caption: The processes of the Carnot engine. Process AB is an isothermal expansion at temperature T_H, BC an adiabatic expansion, CD an isothermal compression at temperature T_C, and DC an adiabatic compression.

introduction.p: When this observation on the efficiency of the Carnot engine is combined with the Kelvin-Planck statement of the second law, we can conclude that a temperature of zero degree kelvin is not reachable since that would imply a possibility of constructing a thermal engine that has 100% efficiency. This gives another way to state the second law of thermodynamics.

p.alert: Another Statement for the Second Law.
p.em: It is impossible to reach a temperature of zero degree kelvin.

subsection.title: Proof of Q_C/Q_H = T_C/T_H in Carnot Cycle
subsection.p:
Since the internal energy of an ideal gas is proportional to temperature, the internal energy does not change in the processes AB and CD in . Applying first law of thermodynamics to these steps and using the formula for work by a gas in an isothermal process, we conclude
\amp Q_H = W_{AB} = nRT_H \ln\left( \frac{V_B}{V_A} \right) \amp Q_C = W_{CD} = nRT_H \ln\left( \frac{V_D}{V_C} \right)
From the adiabatic processes BC and DA we have the following relations.
\amp \textrm{BC process: } T_H V_B^{\gamma-1} = T_C V_C^{\gamma-1} \amp \textrm{DA process: } T_H V_A^{\gamma-1} = T_C V_D^{\gamma-1}
Taking the ratio we find
\frac{V_B}{V_A} = \frac{V_C}{V_D}.
Now, we take the ratio of Eq. to Eq. and use Eq. to obtain the required result.
Q_C/Q_H = T_C/T_H.

exercise.title: The Efficiency of a Carnot Engine

statement.p: A Carnot engine operates between 400^{\circ}\text{C} and 27^{\circ}\text{C}.
(a) What is the efficiency of the Carnot engine?
(b) If the Carnot engine produces 5 kJ of work in each cycle, how much heat must it absorb from the 400^{\circ}\text{C} bath in each cycle.

hint.p: (a) Make sure you express temperature in kelvin scale. (b) Use the efficiency found in the efficiency for arbitrary heat engine.

solution.title: (a)
(b)
solution.p:
(b) We can use the efficiency found to figure out the heat in the engine.
\text{Since }\eta = \dfrac{W}{Q_H},\ \ Q_H = \dfrac{W}{\eta} = \dfrac{5\ \text{kJ}}{0.554} = 9.03\ \text{kJ}.

exercise.title: Heat Flow in a Carnot Engine

statement.p: A Carnot engine operating in a Carnot cycle between 400^{\circ}\text{C} and an unknown lower temperature has an efficiency of 0.3. How much heat must be rejected to the cold bath for every kJ of heat absorbed from the hot bath.

solution.p:
The efficiency of the Carnot engine can be expressed in terms of Q_C and Q_H alone.
\eta_C = \frac{Q_H-Q_C}{Q_H}\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ Q_C = (1-\eta_C) Q_H.
Therefore, if Q_H = 1\text{ kJ}, then
Q_C = (1-0.3) \times 1\ \text{kJ} = 0.7\ \text{kJ}.

statement.p: A Carnot engine working between two heat baths of temperatures 600\text{K} and 273\text{K} completes each cycle in 5\text{ sec}. In each cycle, the engine absorbs 10\text{ kJ} of heat. Find the power of the engine.

hint.p: Find \eta from temperatures and then use it to get W and P=W/\Delta t.

solution.p:
The power P of the engine will be work W divided by time \Delta t.
P = \frac{W}{\Delta t}.
From the definition of efficiency we can obtain W from the heat rejected to the lower temperature bath and the efficiency as follows.
\eta = \frac{W}{Q_H} = \frac{W}{W-Q_C}\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ W = \left( \frac{\eta}{1-\eta}\right)\ Q_C.
The efficiency here is equal to the efficiency of the Carnot cycle.
\eta = 1- \frac{T_C}{T_H}\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \frac{\eta}{1-\eta} = \frac{T_H-T_C}{T_C}.
Putting in the values here
\frac{\eta}{1-\eta} = \frac{600-273}{273} = 1.2.
Therefore,
W = 1.2\times\ Q_C = 1.2\times 10\ \text{kJ} = 12\ \text{kJ}.
This work is done in 5 sec. Therefore, the power is
P = \frac{W}{\Delta t} = \frac{12\ \text{kJ}}{5\ s} = 2400\ \text{W}.

exercise.title: Carnot Cycle with Monatomic Ideal Gas

statement.p: Two moles of a monatomic ideal gas performs a Carnot cycle between 300\text{ K} and 500\text{ K}. The starting volume of the gas before isothermal expansion was 3\times 10^{-3}\text{ m}^3, and it expands to double the volume in the isothermal step. Find the total amount of work done and heat absorbed from the high temperature reservoir in each cycle.

p.p: At any point of the cycle, use ideal gas law. For work for processes use -pdV. For internal energy use (f/2)nRT, with f=3 for monatomic gas.

sidebyside.p: A Carnot engine employs 1.5 moles of the Nitrogen gas as the working substance, which will be considered as a diatomic ideal gas with \gamma = 7/5 at the working temperatures of the engine. The Carnot cycle goes in the cycle A-B-C-D-A with A-B being the isothermal expansion. The volume at points A and C of the cycle are 5 \text{ L} and 150 \text{ L} respectively. The engine operates between two thermal baths of temperature 500\text{K} and 300\text{K}.

ol.li: Find the values of the volume at B and D.
How much heat is absorbed by the gas in the AB-isothermal expansion?
How much work is done by the gas in the AB-isothermal expansion?
How much heat is given up by the gas in the CD-isothermal compression?
How much work is done by the gas in the CD-isothermal compression?
How much work is done by the gas in the BC-adiabatic expansion?
How much work is done by the gas in the DA-adiabatic compression?

Find the value of the efficiency of the engine based on the net work and heat input. Compare this value of the efficiency to the value of the efficiency of the Carnot engine based on the temperatures of the two baths.

hint.p: At any point of the cycle, use ideal gas law. For work for processes use -pdV. For internal energy use (f/2)nRT, with f=5 for diatomic gas.

solution.p:
We have the following known quantities in the Carnot cycle.
\amp V_A = 5\ \text{L};\ \ V_C = 150\ \text{L} \amp T_A = T_B = 500\text{K};\ \ T_C= T_D = 300\text{K}
The other parameters we have are
n = 1.5\ \text{mol};\ \ \gamma = \frac{7}{5}
Find the values of the volume at B and D.
The process DA is adiabatic process. Therefore,
T_A V_A^{\gamma-1} = T_D V_D^{\gamma-1}.
This gives
V_D = \left(T_A/ T_D\right)^{1/(\gamma-1)}\ V_A = \left(\frac{500}{300}\right)^{5/2}\times 5\ \text{L} = 17.9\ \text{L}.
From the adiabatic process BC we get
V_B = 41.8 \text{ L}.
How much heat is absorbed by the gas in the AB-isothermal expansion?
Q_{AB} \amp = n RT_A \ln\left( \frac{V_B}{V_A}\right) \amp = 1.5\times8.31\times 500\times \ln\left( \frac{41.8}{5}\right) = 13,200\ \text{J} \equiv Q_H.
How much work is done by the gas in the AB-isothermal expansion?
Since the temperature is constant, and for an ideal gas, the internal energy does not change in a constant-temperature process.
W_{AB} = Q_{AB} = 13,200\ \text{J}.
How much heat is given up by the gas in the CD-isothermal compression?
Q_{CD} \amp = n RT_A \ln\left( \frac{V_D}{V_C}\right) \amp = 1.5\times8.31\times 300\times \ln\left( \frac{17.9}{150}\right) = -8,000\ \text{J} \equiv -Q_C.
How much work is done by the gas in the CD-isothermal compression?
W_{CD} = Q_{CD} = -8,000\ \text{J}.
How much work is done by the gas in the BC-adiabatic expansion?
The adiabaticity of process gives the following for the work by the gas.
W_{BC} = -\Delta U = -\frac{5}{2} n R(T_C - T_B) = 6,200\ \text{J}.
How much work is done by the gas in the DA-adiabatic compression?
The adiabaticity of process gives the following for the work by the gas.
W_{DA} = -\Delta U = -\frac{5}{2} n R(T_A - T_D) = -6,200\ \text{J}.
Find the value of the efficiency of the engine based on the net work and heat input. Compare this value of the efficiency to the value of the efficiency of the Carnot engine based on the temperatures of the two baths.
The net work:
W \amp = W_{AB} + W_{BC} + W_{CD} + W_{DA} \amp = 13,200\ \text{J} + 6,200\ \text{J} -8,000\ \text{J} -6,200\ \text{J} = 5,200 \ \text{J}.
The heat input in the AB-process is
Q_H = 13,200\ \text{J}.
Therefore, the efficiency of the cycle is
\eta =\frac{5,200 \ \text{J}}{13,200\ \text{J}} = 0.394\ \ \text{or}\ \ 39.4\%.
